QDs were prepared in the aqueous solution by the hydrolysis and oxidation of SnCl
source material. The average grain size of the QDs was 2.23 nm from HRTEM observation. The rutile
of the prepared QDs was confirmed from the XRD pattern, HRTEM observation and
XPS spectrum. The fluorescence spectra of the SnO
QDs show intensity peaked at an emission

were evaluated in the background solutions of deionized water, deionized water with Fe
reclaimed water and sea water. The limit of detection was as low as 0.01 ppm for Ni
Logarithmic correlation of ﬂuorescence emission intensity against Ni
QDs were prepared in the aqueous solution by the hydrolysis and oxidation of SnCl
source material. The average grain size of the QDs was 2.23 nmfromHRTEMobservation. The rutile
of the prepared QDs was conﬁrmed fromthe XRD pattern, HRTEMobservation and XPS
spectrum. The ﬂuorescence spectra of the SnO
QDs showintensity peaked at an emission wavelength
QDs showed a ﬂuorescence response to various heavy metal ions and the response
of 2.48 was observed to be 100 ppm Ni
the background solutions of deionized water, deionized water with Fe
sea water. The limit of detection was as low as 0.01 ppm for Ni
great potential in the sensor development for the detection of heavy metal ions in contaminated water.
The ﬁrst principle calculation demonstrated that Ni
had an adsorption energy of 7.65 and
13.46 eV, respectively. The ﬂuorescence response was found to be dependent on the adsorption energy
as well as ion radius of heavy metal ions. The mechanism of ﬂuorescence response was discussed
based on the interaction between Sn vacancies and Ni
ions. The ﬂuorescence emission intensity was
formulated as a function of Ni
concentration. 71% of Sn vacancies on the surface were left vacant,
ions. The density of active Sn vacancies was the crucial factor that
determined the ﬂuorescence response of SnO
